instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-00293: What is 820-00293? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing CPU-VCORE
threads.message:
[INDENT]Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00293</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Schematics and BV. I have all rails present apart from the following :

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
PPVCCEDRAM_S0_CPU
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>

I believe the last 2 won't have any voltages until the top 2 are working.

Both the top 2 come from the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>

I've check the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and I have:

SDA - 1v
SCLK - 1v
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
both VIN & VCC have the correct voltages.

For shit's and giggles I change the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> this didn't make any difference.

Next I've looked at the <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7410</CHIP>, <CHIP>U7420</CHIP> & <CHIP>U7430</CHIP>

All of them have 2.5v on the PWM line, 0.00v on the FCCM line and the correct voltages on VCC, VIN, PVCC.

On <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>) which is working. I get 5.0v on both PWM and FCCM and Vout of 1.02v (schematics says Vout 0.55 - 1.15v)

So maybe with <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> working and with all Vin voltage present this rules out the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

Initially as mentioned this was liquid damaged and had a short to ground on the <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> which was causing PPBUS to short. I changed this and now I have all the power rails.

Not sure what to check next.[/INDENT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing CPU-VCORE
threads.message: How long do I have to wait until I get a response to my problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing CPU-VCORE
threads.message: Where was the liquid damage located first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing CPU-VCORE
threads.message: <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> was shorted putting PPBUS straight to the CPU. CPU was instantly killed, this board is done sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing CPU-VCORE
threads.message: $29 for you just to come to that a assumption without even asking me any readings!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing CPU-VCORE
threads.message: It’s a high side mosfet it’s going to pretty much always kill what’s on it line.....Jesus lmfao he’s just being honest...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing CPU-VCORE
threads.message: There is nothing to measure, the CPU is 100% dead once PPBUS got to it. Be glad I told you, you could have wasted many more hours on this.
